KE / Domain: Sputum inflammatory cell profiles and microbiome
AOP entity (KE/KER): Organism-level outcome; relationship to airway inflammation and oxidative stress; potential link to lung function decline
Input (manipulation / sample): Human sputum samples from healthy and diseased subjects (e.g., COPD, asthma); bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) samples
Method / Assay (SOP notes): Sputum collection and processing for cell differential counts. Flow cytometry or microscopy for inflammatory cell quantification (neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, lymphocytes). 16S rRNA sequencing for microbiome analysis. Cytokine and chemokine measurements (multiplex assays or ELISA).
Output / Measurement: Inflammatory cell counts and percentages (neutrophils %, eosinophils %, macrophages %, lymphocytes %); Microbiome composition (alpha diversity, beta diversity, taxonomic abundance); Cytokine/chemokine levels (IL-6, IL-8, TNF-α, etc.); Correlation between cellular inflammation and microbiome
Interpretation / Context fields to captu: Subject demographics (age, sex, smoking status); disease diagnosis and severity; medication use; sputum collection method (spontaneous vs induced); sample processing time; cell viability; flow cytometry panels and gating strategy; sequencing platform and depth; bioinformatics pipeline version; statistical analysis methods
Exemplar peer-reviewed manuscripts: Cobos-Uribe et al. (2025). Human sputum microbiome composition and sputum inflammatory cell profiles are altered with [condition].
Protocol / SOP notes (attach): Include sputum induction protocol (if applicable), sample processing workflow, cell counting method, flow cytometry antibody panels, DNA extraction protocol, 16S sequencing primers and protocol, bioinformatics pipeline, quality control criteria
S&T considerations (ontology / mapping): Biolink: MeasurementProcess; OBI: flow cytometry assay, 16S rRNA gene sequencing assay; Mapping: inflammatory cell quantification, microbiome analysis; ENVO: sputum sample; Clinical biomarker potential

KE / Domain: Mucociliary clearance and mucus properties (related to sputum)
AOP entity (KE/KER): Supports understanding of mucus transport and clearance; relationship to sputum production
Input (manipulation / sample): In vivo intranasal μOCT imaging; ex vivo airway tissue
Method / Assay (SOP notes): Micro-Optical Coherence Tomography (μOCT) for visualizing mucus layer, measuring mucociliary transport rate, and assessing airway surface properties. Non-invasive in vivo imaging. Provides microstructural information about mucus and mucociliary clearance that relates to sputum production capacity.
Output / Measurement: Mucociliary transport rate (mm/min); Mucus layer thickness; ASL depth (µm); Ciliary beat frequency (Hz); Functional assessment of clearance mechanisms
Interpretation / Context fields to captu: Subject characteristics; disease state (CF, healthy); anatomical location; environmental conditions; imaging parameters; analysis algorithm; correlation with clinical mucus/sputum production
Exemplar peer-reviewed manuscripts: Leung HM, Birket SE, Hyun C, Ford TN, Cui D, Solomon GM, et al. (2019). Intranasal micro-optical coherence tomography imaging for cystic fibrosis studies. Sci Transl Med. 11(504).
Protocol / SOP notes (attach): Include μOCT imaging protocol, mucus visualization methods, transport rate calculation, correlation with clinical assessments of mucus production or sputum characteristics
S&T considerations (ontology / mapping): Biolink: MeasurementProcess; OBI: optical coherence tomography assay; Mapping: mucociliary clearance function; Relationship to sputum production and clearance capacity
